qas.question: What is pronounced [a] in Southern Russian?

answers.text: unstressed /e/ and /a/ following palatalized consonants and preceding a stressed syllable

qas.question: What is pronounced [ɪ] in Moscow's dialect?

answers.text: unstressed /e/ and /a/ following palatalized consonants and preceding a stressed syllable

qas.question: What does Southern Russian have a linguistic continuum with?

answers.text: modern Belarusian and some dialects of Ukrainian (Eastern Polesian)

plausible_answers.text: unstressed /e/ and /a/ following palatalized consonants and preceding a stressed syllable are not reduced to [ɪ]

qas.question: What is called yakanye in Standard and Northern dialects?

plausible_answers.text: modern Belarusian and some dialects of Ukrainian (Eastern Polesian)

qas.question: What do Standard dialects have a linguistic continuum with?

plausible_answers.text: final /tʲ/ in 3rd person forms of verbs

qas.question: In a semivowel what is unpalatalized?
What consonants are included in Belarusian?
What do consonants include in Ukranian?

context: In the Southern Russian dialects, instances of <a0_0><a1_0><b3_0>unstressed /e/ and /a/ following palatalized consonants and preceding a stressed syllable<a1_0/><a0_0/> are not reduced to [ɪ]<b3_0/> (as occurs in the Moscow dialect), being instead pronounced [a] in such positions (e.g. несли is pronounced [nʲaˈslʲi], not [nʲɪsˈlʲi]) – this is called yakanye/яканье. Consonants include <b7_0>a fricative /ɣ/, a semivowel /w~u̯/ and /x~xv~xw/<b7_0/>, whereas the Standard and Northern dialects have the consonants <b6_0>/ɡ/, /v/, and final /l/ and /f/<b6_0/>, respectively. The morphology features a palatalized <b5_0>final /tʲ/ in 3rd person forms of verbs<b5_0/> (this is unpalatalized in the Standard and Northern dialects). Some of these features such as akanye/yakanye, a debuccalized or lenited /ɡ/, a semivowel /w~u̯/ and palatalized final /tʲ/ in 3rd person forms of verbs are also present in <a2_0><b4_0>modern Belarusian and some dialects of Ukrainian (Eastern Polesian)<b4_0/><a2_0/>, indicating a linguistic continuum.
